profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-04-29 19:56:28 UTC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Roberta Griffith was born in Hillsdale, Michigan in 1937 and graduated from Battle Creek High School in 1955. She received a full-tuition scholarship in painting at the Instituto Allende, San Miguel de Allende, Mexico from 1957-58, followed by two years with full-tuition scholarships at the Chouinard Art Institute in Los Angeles (now CalArts), California, graduating with her Bachelor of Fine Arts in 1960. She earned an MFA from Southern Illinois University at Carbondale in 1962.

In 1962, Roberta received a two-year Fulbright Research Grant to study in Barcelona, Spain where she studied ceramics with mentor Josep Llorens Artigas at L'Escola Massana School of Art and Design, conducted research on Spanish Folk Ceramics, and continued painting. She returned to the States in 1965 and worked for one year as ceramic designer at Design Tecnics in Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania. In 1966, she joined the faculty at Hartwick College in Oneonta, New York, becoming an associate professor in 1972, Chair of the Department of Art in 1974, full professor in 1975, and the Arkell Hall Endowed Chair and Professor of Art from 1979 until her retirement in 2008.

Roberta's techniques involve both hand-built ceramic sculptures, wheel thrown shapes, bisque molds, and plaster press molds with firings at low and high-fire kiln temperatures. She often creates mixed media installations, 2-D and 3-D art, and multiple series exhibitions. Her work has been exhibited both nationally and internationally and she has had over thirty solo shows. Reviews and pictures of her work have appeared in books, magazines, exhibition catalogues, and newspapers internationally. Her artwork is included in museums and private collections in the United States, Spain, Mexico, Italy, England, Sweden, Japan, and China. She is the North American correspondent for Ceramica magazine in Madrid, Spain. Most recently, Roberta's ceramics were included in prestigious exhibitions at the Yixing City Museum, Yixing, China (2017) and at the Yingge Ceramics Museum, New Taipei City, Taiwan (2018).

She has received numerous prestigious prizes and awards including: a National Endowment of the Humanities Grant in 1991 which allowed her to pursue her research interests in Pre-Columbian and Mesoamerican art and archaeology; the Teacher/Scholar Award from Hartwick College in 1996; the Charles W. Hunt Award for Lifetime Achievement in the Arts and Service to the Arts Community from the Upper Catskill Community Council of the Arts in Oneonta, New York in 2001; and National Society of Daughters of the American Revolution American Heritage Award for Women in the Arts in 2018. Her biography continues to be included in Marquis Who's Who, Who's Who of American Women, Who's Who in American Education, and Who's Who in American Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Roberta Griffith, member of the Hartwick College faculty for forty-two years from 1966 to 2008, taught ceramics, drawing, and painting to hundreds of Hartwick students. She served as chair of the Art Department for seventeen years, during which time the College's Studio Art and Art History majors were established and the department was accredited by the National Association of Schools of Art and Design. In 1979, she was appointed the Arkell Hall Endowed Chair and Professor of Art, a position she held until her retirement in 2008. In 1995, she received Hartwick's Teacher Scholar Award. She is currently Professor Emerita of Art.
Roberta deposited the bulk of her papers in the Hartwick College Archives in 2006 and donated the collection to the College in 2019.
